There are numerous religious (Read More) places in Rajasthan such as Nathdwara, Pushkar and Bikaner. Here is the list of 20 Religious Places In Rajasthan For A Spiritual Escape 1. Brahma Temple, Pushkar 4.4 /5 Brahma Temple, situated in the sacred town of Pushkar, Rajasthan, stands as one of the few temples dedicated to Lord Brahma in the world. Surrounded by Pushkar Lake, the temple boasts a unique architectural style with a red spire and intricately carved silver doors, marking its significance in the Hindu pilgrimage circuit.Timings: 6:00 AM to 8:00 PM. Known for: Its rare dedication to Lord Brahma, its role in the famous Pushkar Fair, and its spiritual significance in the heart of the Pushkar town. Read More 2. Shrinathji Temple, Nathdwara 3.7 /5 View 5+ photos Shrinathji Temple, located in Nathdwara, Rajasthan, is an iconic religious hub dedicated to Lord Krishna. The temple is famous for its central deity, an idol of the seven-year-old infant form of Krishna known as Shrinathji. The intricate artwork and the daily rituals at the temple attract pilgrims and art enthusiasts from all over the world.Timings: Different darshan timings are observed throughout the day, starting from 5:30 AM to 8:15 PM Known for: Its beautiful idol of Lord Krishna, the exquisite Pichwai paintings, and its significant religious and cultural prominence. Read More 3. Eklingji Temple, Udaipur 4.4 /5 View 7+ photos Eklingji Temple, situated near Udaipur, is a revered pilgrimage site dedicated to Lord Shiva. The temple complex boasts of 108 intricately carved temples made out of marble and granite, showcasing the rich architectural heritage of Rajasthan. The chief deity, Lord Shiva's four-faced idol, is carved out of black marble, representing his various forms.Timings: 4:30 AM - 7:00 PM (Morning), 5:00 PM - 7:30 PM (Evening) Known for: Its architectural brilliance, the four-faced idol of Lord Shiva, and its significance in Mewar's history. Read More 4. Karni Mata Temple, Bikaner 4.2 /5 View 5+ photos Karni Mata Temple in Bikaner, often referred to as the "Temple of Rats", is a unique 600-year-old shrine dedicated to Karni Mata, an incarnation of Goddess Durga. Housing thousands of rats that are revered and protected, the temple offers an unparalleled spiritual experience for devotees and tourists alike. It's believed that spotting a white rat amidst the swarm is especially auspicious.Timings: 4:00 AM - 10:00 PM Known for: Its vast population of revered rats and the legend associated with them. Govind Ji Temple, Jaipur 4.6 /5 The Govind Ji Temple in Jaipur is a significant and historic temple dedicated to Lord Krishna. Situated within the City Palace complex, it showcases an epitome of royal grandeur and religious devotion. The temple is known for its mesmerizing art and architecture, and the rituals performed here attract devotees from all corners of the country.Timings: 5:00 AM - 11:30 AM and 5:30 PM - 9:30 PM  Known for: Its spiritual ambiance, magnificent structure, and as a central place of worship in Jaipur. Read More 6. Rani Sati Temple, Jhunjhunu 3.4 /5 The Rani Sati Temple in Jhunjhunu is one of the most distinguished temples in Rajasthan, dedicated to Rani Sati, a legendary Rajasthani bride who became a symbol of marital devotion. The temple doesn't represent any particular religion but upholds the spirit of righteousness and truth. Its architectural beauty, intricate carvings, and murals are a testament to the region's historic craftsmanship.Timings: 6:00 AM - 12:00 PM and 4:00 PM - 10:00 PM Known for: Its rich history, splendid architecture, and being one of the most significant pilgrimage sites in Rajasthan. Read More 7. Birla Temple, Jaipur 4.4 /5 The Birla Temple in Jaipur, also known as the Laxmi Narayan Temple, is an iconic landmark that showcases contemporary architecture with traditional designs. Constructed purely in white marble, this temple stands as a symbol of the secular traditions India follows, with its sculptures based on mythological themes and an image of Mahatma Gandhi etched to signify the unity of all religions.Timings: 8:00 AM - 12:00 PM and 4:00 PM - 8:00 PM  Known for: Majestic architecture, serene ambiance, and the beautiful carvings of Hindu gods and goddesses. Read More 8. Harihara Temples, Osian 3.1 /5 The Harihara Temples in Osian, Rajasthan, are significant structures reflecting the blend of Shaivism and Vaishnavism. These temples, built during the medieval period, represent the syncretic deity Harihara, a fusion of Lord Vishnu (Hari) and Lord Shiva (Hara). The architectural marvel and the carvings on the temple highlight the rich cultural and religious heritage of Osian.Timings: 8:00 AM - 6:00 PM Known for: Unique amalgamation of Shaivism and Vaishnavism and intricate carvings. Read More 9. Dilwara Temples, Mount-abu 4.6 /5 View 23+ photos The Dilwara Temples in Mount Abu, Rajasthan, epitomize the pinnacle of Jain temple architecture with their exquisitely carved marble details. Built between the 11th and 13th centuries, these temples are an intricate blend of simplicity in faith and complexity in craftsmanship. The temples primarily include the Vimal Vasahi Temple and the Luna Vasahi Temple, each dedicated to different Jain Tirthankaras.Timings: 12:00 PM - 5:00 PM Known for: Exquisite marble carvings and historic Jain pilgrimage significance. Read More 10. Galtaji Temple, Jaipur View 7+ photos Galtaji Temple, located amidst the Aravali Hills in Jaipur, is an ancient pilgrimage site, renowned for its natural water springs and architectural beauty. Often referred to as the "Monkey Temple", it attracts both devotees and tourists alike, as the surroundings are inhabited by numerous monkeys. The temple complex consists of several shrines, with the main temple dedicated to Galtaji Maharaj, a saint.Timings: 5:00 AM - 9:00 PM Known for: Natural water springs, panoramic views, and its resident monkey population. Read More 11. Ranakpur Jain Temple, Ranakpur 4.1 /5 View 22+ photos Ranakpur Jain Temple, situated in the heart of Ranakpur, Rajasthan, is a marvel of marble architecture and is renowned for its intricate carvings and magnificent design. Dedicated to Adinatha, the first Jain Tirthankar, the temple complex comprises several shrines, with the main temple boasting 1,444 uniquely carved pillars that change colors with the shifting sunlight.Timings: 12:00 PM - 5:00 PM for tourists (Jain rituals take place in the morning.) Known for: Intricate marble carvings, numerous pillars, and being one of the five most important pilgrimage sites for Jains. Read More 12. Ajmer Sharif Dargah, Ajmer 4.6 /5 View 20+ photos Ajmer Sharif Dargah, located in Ajmer, Rajasthan, is a renowned Sufi shrine dedicated to the 13th-century saint, Khwaja Moinuddin Chishti. Revered by people of all religions, the shrine is a symbol of unity and peace. The serene ambiance, coupled with the soulful qawwalis performed daily, offers a spiritual experience that leaves visitors in awe.Timings: 5:00 AM - 9:00 PM (Timings may vary during special festivals or occasions) Known for: Its spiritual ambiance, rich history, and the famous annual Urs festival celebrating the saint's death anniversary. Read More 13. Khatushyam Mandir, Sikar 3.0 /5 Khatushyam Mandir, situated in Sikar district of Rajasthan, is a significant religious site dedicated to Khatushyam Ji, an incarnation of Lord Krishna. According to legends, the deity represents the head of Barbarika, a brave warrior, which Lord Krishna had preserved. The temple attracts a vast number of pilgrims, especially during the famous 'Khatushyam Ji Fair.'Timings: 5:00 AM - 9:00 PM Known for: Its spiritual significance, beautiful architecture, and the renowned 'Khatushyam Ji Fair.' Read More 14. Jirawala Parshwanath, Rajasthan Jirawala Parshwanath Temple, located in the Sirohi district of Rajasthan, is an ancient and revered Jain pilgrimage site. The temple is dedicated to Lord Parshwanath, the 23rd Tirthankara, and is renowned for its intricate carvings, beautiful artwork, and the spiritual serenity it offers. It is believed that the temple was constructed around the 13th century, and since then, it has been a beacon for Jain devotees.Timings: 6:00 AM - 8:00 PM Known for: Its historical significance, beautiful architecture, and being a vital Jain pilgrimage spot. Read More 15. Ramdevra Temple, Jaisalmer 3.0 /5 Ramdevra Temple, situated in Jaisalmer, Rajasthan, is a prominent pilgrimage spot dedicated to the folk deity Baba Ramdevji. Revered by both Hindus and Muslims, Baba Ramdevji, believed to be an incarnation of Lord Krishna, performed numerous miracles and won the hearts of people with his selfless acts and devotion. The temple stands on the very spot where Baba Ramdevji took samadhi and attracts numerous devotees, especially during the Ramdevra Fair held in August and September.Timings: 5:00 AM - 9:00 PMKnown for: The samadhi of Baba Ramdevji, its spiritual significance, and the grand Ramdevra Fair. Read More 16. Ajmer Jain Temple, Ajmer 4.5 /5 The Ajmer Jain Temple, also known as Soniji Ki Nasiyan, is a striking red temple that stands as an emblem of rich Jain heritage in Ajmer. Adorned with intricate carvings and gold-plated wooden figures, the main chamber of the temple, known as the 'Swarna Nagari', recreates key events and cities from Jain scriptures. This temple is not just a pilgrimage site for Jains, but also a prominent tourist attraction, given its splendid architecture and historical relevance.Timings: 8:30 AM - 4:30 PM Known for: Intricate carvings, the gold-plated 'Swarna Nagari', and its religious and historical significance. Read More 17. Nareli Jain Temple, Ajmer 4.7 /5 View 5+ photos Nareli Jain Temple, situated on the outskirts of Ajmer, is a marvelous amalgamation of traditional and contemporary Jain architecture. The temple, dedicated to the 24th Tirthankara, Lord Mahavira, is surrounded by 23 other smaller temples on the hills behind it, known as the "Chaumukha". The serene and picturesque setting of the temple, combined with its unique design, attracts both Jain devotees and tourists.Timings: 6:30 AM - 7:00 PM  Known for: Beautiful blend of modern and traditional architecture, the scenic beauty, and the representation of the 24 Tirthankaras. Read More 18. Ambika Mata Temple Ambika Mata Temple, located in the Jagat village of Rajasthan, is often referred to as the 'Khajuraho of Rajasthan' due to its intricate and exquisite carvings. This 10th-century temple, dedicated to Goddess Ambika, a form of Goddess Durga, is carved out of a rock cleft and boasts of an unparalleled architectural beauty. The sanctum sanctorum houses a black stone idol of the goddess, showcasing her as a fierce warrior.Timings: 5:00 AM - 9:00 PM Known for: Intricate carvings, ancient architecture, and the black stone idol of Goddess Ambika. 19. Shri Kaila Devi Temple Kaila Devi Temple, situated in Karauli, Rajasthan, is a significant Hindu pilgrimage site dedicated to the goddess Kaila Devi. As part of the historic chain of Shakti Peethas spread across the subcontinent, the temple attracts devotees from far and wide, especially during the annual Kaila Devi Fair. The temple's serene environment on the banks of the Kalisil river and its intricate architectural beauty further accentuate its spiritual allure.Timings: 5:00 AM - 10:00 PM Known for: Its religious significance, annual Kaila Devi Fair, and picturesque location by the Kalisil river. 20. Tijara Jain Temple Tijara Jain Temple, located in Tijara, Rajasthan, is a significant Jain pilgrimage site dedicated to the 8th Tirthankara, Shri Chandra Prabhu Bhagwan. The temple is particularly renowned for its exquisite architectural designs and the miraculous idol of Bhagwan Chandra Prabhu, which was excavated in 1956 after being buried for several centuries. This discovery has since made Tijara a prominent religious destination for Jain devotees.Timings: 6:00 AM - 8:00 PM Known for: Its historical significance, beautiful architecture, and the miraculous idol of the 8th Tirthankara. Which of these religious places in Rajasthan will you add to your bucket list?
